newsitem.title: UK: London gold edges sideways, considers downside.
newsitem.headline: London gold edges sideways, considers downside.

text.p: The precious metals were locked in narrow price ranges on Monday after shifting downwards last week, and the market's attitude remained bearish, dealers said. "Generally the feeling is prices will head lower. The charts aren't particularly positive," a dealer said. "But people may have become too bearish."
Bullion fixed at $380.00 an ounce, unchanged from Friday afternoon's fixing and barely changed from the London close of $379.90/$380.40.
Activity overnight was lacklustre as Hong Kong markets were closed for the Chung Yeung holiday, dealers said.
Downtrending prices were meeting little resistance from investor and speculative interest, which has been scant and expected to remain that way while U.S. stock market surge.

But some dealers said they expected gold's $380 support level to hold until after the end-of-month expiry of options, which give the right but not the obligation to buy or sell metal at a given price.
"There is options support and physical support at the moment," a dealer said. But gold's potential to break out higher in the near term was severely limited, analysts said.

One dealer saw a possibility of a slight bounce towards $381.00, but if it managed to get below support around $379.25 prices were pegged to head to the bottom of the current $378-$382 price range. But any action would almost certainly originate in New York, as the London bullion market has been lifeless, dealers said.
Silver was two cents weaker at $4.89/$4.91 an ounce.

As the recent leader of the precious metals complex, silver looked on shaky territory and was likely to revisit the September 20 low of $4.81 if prices broke through initial support at $4.85, dealers said.
The platinum group metals were weaker and vulnerable to the downside after drifting lower last week.
Platinum was off $1.00 at $382.50/$383.50 an ounce compared to Friday's London close.
But it was likely to hold above critical support at $380 in the near term, dealers said.
Palladium, which sank to 3-1/2 year lows last week, was down $0.25 at $115.25/$116.25.
